properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1Schiedam, HollandIn 1396, following a fall whilst skating, Lidwina developed walking difficulties, headaches and violent pains in her teeth. Within a few years, she was walking with difficulty and a weakness in her face caused her lip to droop on one side. Throughout the remainder of her life, Lidwina\'s condition slowly deteriorated, although with apparent periods of remission. During her life and subsequently, Lidwina\'s forbearance with her symptoms led to the development of a cult. She was canonised in 1890 and is now the patron saint of skaters. The bones of St Lidwina were discovered in 1947 and do show evidence of restricted mobility in the legs and right arm. Though it had previously been suggested that St Lidwina had MS, doubts have been cast on this and the evidence is not considered persuasive.

Posted by Mpenn1London, EnglandThe first identifiable instance of MS does not occur until the early 19th century. Augustus d\'Este (1794-1848) was a grandson of George III. The course of his MS, which wasn\'t diagnosed during his lifetime, is known from the diaries and records he kept from 1822 until shortly before his death. D\'Este\'s initial symptom was the onset of blurred vision, which cleared up without treatment and then recurred a few years later. He later had episodes of double vision, weakness in his legs, numbness, bladder and bowel problems and impotence. By 1843 he was experiencing persistent symptoms including tremor and nocturnal spasms and in his last years became confined to his bed.

Posted by Mpenn1London, EnglandRobert Carswell (1793-1857) The first important step toward a recognition of the pathology of MS came with a discovery by Robert Carswell, a pathologist of the mid 19th century. During a postmortem, Carswell found strange lesions in the spinal cord of an unfortunate subject. Unaware of their cause, he meticulously recorded their gross appearance. Despite his major contribution in describing the pathology of MS lesions, Carswell did not record any clinical associations with his observations. The clinical symptoms of MS were not linked to the \'diseased\' state Carswell described until much later.

Posted by Mpenn1Paris, FranceJean Cruveilhier (1791 - 1874) An eminent Parisian anatomist who also lived through the mid 19th century. Cruveilhier, like Robert Carswell, described the pathology of the lesions seen in MS and although the two men worked independently, their illustrations appeared almost simultaneously. Much debate exists as to which illustration was made first. However, Cruveilhier\'s version, seen in this slide, was not published until 1842.

Posted by Mpenn1GermanyFriedrich von Frerichs (1819-1885) In 1849, the German pathologist Friedrich Theodor von Frerichs, brought medical recognition of MS a step closer by elaborating on the clinical description of MS provided by Cruveilhier and identifying specific symptoms and key features of the illness. Frerichs\' clinical account for the first time recognised remissions as a characteristic feature of MS. In addition, he described nystagmus as a symptom of the disease, this physical sign later being incorporated into the famous Charcot\'s triad. Frerichs also made a major contribution by providing the first medical description of mental disorders in MS, recognising the possible impact of the disease on cognitive and other higher functions of the brain.

Posted by Mpenn1Vienna, AustriaCarl Rokitansky (1804  1878) One of the most outstanding morphological pathologists of the 19th century. Working at the Institute of Pathology in Vienna, he was one of the first to examine MS lesions microscopically.Rokitansky made a particularly important observation in 1857 when he noticed \'fatty corpuscles\' in the MS lesions.

Posted by Mpenn1GermanyEduard Rindfleisch (1836-1908) Reported a key finding that paved the way for theories of inflammatory involvement in the aetiology of MS. He noticed that, consistently in all the specimens, a blood vessel was present at the centre of each lesion. Rindfleisch came to believe that a primary state of inflammation was responsible for the demyelination.

Posted by Mpenn1Paris, FranceJean-Martin Charcot (1825-1893) an eminent 19th century French neurologist who worked at the SalpÃtriÀre hospital, Paris. Without doubt, Charcot was one of the most important characters in the history of MS, his findings representing a huge breakthrough for the clinical understanding of the disease. Charcot was the first to make definite links between the hitherto mysterious symptomatology, now known to be MS, and the pathological changes seen in post-mortem samples. For the first time, almost forty years after the discovery of the lesions, the clinical condition was described by Charcot as \'sclrose en plaques\' and MS as recognised as a distinct disease entity. Charcot also gave the first complete histological account of MS lesions, describing many important features including loss of myelin and proliferation of glial fibres and nuclei.
Posted by Mpenn1Lyon, FranceMyelin Discovered by Louis Ranvier
Posted by Mpenn1Paris, FrancePierre Marie (1853-1940) provided the next great step in the history of MS, by suggesting for the first time that the disease might be caused by an infectious agent.
Posted by Mpenn1Edinburgh, ScotlandDetailed microscopic description made by James Dawson revealed the basic damage done in MS

Posted by Mpenn1London, EnglandBruce Fredrick Cummings (1889 - 1919) Cummings was tragically afflicted with MS and fought a constant battle against his progressive disability. Under the pseudonym WNP Barbellion, Cummings gave a moving personal account of his suffering in his book The Journal of a Disappointed Man, published in 1919. The book remains one of the finest personal testimonies of an MS sufferer, with the entries detailing the gradual incapacitation brought by the disease. Cummings eloquently highlights the cruelty of MS and his grief at being relentlessly robbed of his physical abilities.

Posted by Mpenn1London, EnglandDr Russell Brain (1895-1966) Brain went on to produce a textbook entitled Diseases of the Nervous System which contained a section on MS. The textbook was first published in 1933 and then regularly revised by Brain himself until his death in 1966. rain was the first to collect statistical data concerning the incidence and course of MS. He also gave lucid accounts of the underlying pathology, so accurate that they still stand almost unchanged today. Developments in treatment for MS can be followed from the clinical narratives in each edition. His comprehension of MS was extremely precise and many of the opinions and predictions expressed in his earlier work have since been proved correct.

Posted by Mpenn1Cambridge, MADerek Denny-Brown (1901 - 1981) a professor of Neurology working at Harvard, USA, provided the key to this uncertainty from experiments on damaged peripheral neurons. Denny-Brown observed that when a damaged nerve was stimulated, it failed to pass the impulse to the connected muscle. He concluded that it was the demyelination associated with lesions on the nerve that was responsible for the block in conduction. Demyclination was therefore shown to prevent or slow the conduction of impulses through a nerve.
Posted by Mpenn1New York City, NYThe National MS Society founded by Sylvia Lawry

Posted by Mpenn1New York City, NYElvin A Kabat (1914 - 2000) During the 1940s Dr Elvin Kabat was investigating the immunological response seen in all MS patients. Based at the Department of Neurology, Columbia University, USA, Kabat used the recently developed technique of electrophoresis to study samples from MS patients. Kabat compared the electrophoretic pattern of proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum from controls and MS patients and found that the CSF from MS patients contained an increased proportion of gamma globulins. Kabat\'s key finding confirmed an immunological component in MS, a concept first postulated in the late 19th century. Subsequent research has tried to understand why the immune system generates this inappropriate response and potential treatments have focused on trying to suppress the immunological activity which leads to demyelination.
Posted by Mpenn1Cleveland, OHThe Ohio Buckeye Chapter is founded!
Posted by Mpenn1New York City, NYDefinite criteria for MS diagnosis developed by NMSS expert committee

Posted by Mpenn1Newark, NJJohn W Prineas (1937-present) used specialised light and electron microscopy techniques to examine the detailed histology of MS lesions, providing clues about their pathogenesis. It had already been shown that MS lesions contain lymphocytes and plasma cells, suggesting the existence of a local immune response to an unknown antigen, but Prineas\'s observations led him to conclude that both macrophages and microglial cells are required for the digestion of myelin. Prineas\'s studies also suggest that within chronic lesions there is a continued expression and processing of antigen in the absence of fresh lesion formation.
Posted by Mpenn1London, EnglandIan R Young (1932-present) published an article demonstrating the effective application of MRI in the diagnosis of MS.

Posted by Mpenn1Philadelphia, PARobert I Grossman (1945-present) found that when using the enhancing agent gadolinium-DPTA, some MRI lesions enhance while others do not. Grossman recognised that the gadolinium enhancement identified breakdown of the blood-brain barrier, indicating areas of inflammation.
Posted by Mpenn1Washington, DCBeta-interferon 1b (Betaseron) approved as the first drug to alter the course of MS

properties.name: 2007 MS Walk - Cleveland
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1351 Canal Road, Cleveland, OH 44113MS Walk Tower City Amphitheater Cleveland, Ohio Saturday, April 28, 2007 Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Tower City Amphitheater on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at the Tower City Amphitheater in the Flats. Once checked in, walkers will traverse the beautiful city streets of Cleveland, before heading back to the Finish Line at Tower City Amphitheater for a celebratory lunch and some great entertainment! The entire route is 6 miles long. There is also a 3-mile short route available. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk.

properties.name: MS WALK - Akron
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn17100 Riverview Rd,, Peninsula, OH 44264MS Walk Boston Mills Ski Resort Akron Area Saturday, April 28, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at Boston Mills Ski Resort on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at Boston Mill Ski Resort in the Cuyahoga Valley Recreation Area. Once checked in, walkers will be bussed to the start of the MS Walk. From there, walkers will discover the beauty of the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail. The entire walk is 6 miles long. There is also a 3-mile short rout available. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk.

properties.name: MS WALk - McConnelsville
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn17924 Cutler Lake Road, Blue Rock, OH 43720MS Walk Muskingum River Parkway McConnelsville, Ohio Friday, April 13, 2007 Check in begins at 6:00 p.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate our 2nd Annual MS Walk at the Muskingum River Parkway on Friday, April 13, 2007. The MS Walk will begin and end at the Muskingum River Parkway, which is located one mile from town. Plans are underway to make this year’s event a nice evening full of fun and festivities in support of those living with multiple sclerosis, their families and caregivers.

properties.name: MS WALk - McConnelsville
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn17924 Cutler Lake Road, Blue Rock, OH 43720MS Walk Muskingum River Parkway McConnelsville, Ohio Friday, April 13, 2007 Check in begins at 6:00 p.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate our 2nd Annual MS Walk at the Muskingum River Parkway on Friday, April 13, 2007. properties.name: MS Walk - Athens
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1701 East State Street Athens, OH 45701MS Walk Athens Community Center Athens, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Athens Community Center on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS Walk will begin and end at the Athens Community Center, which is located at 701 East State Street in Athens. You will enter through the front doors. Check in for the MS Walk will take place in the gathering hall. Ample parking for this event is available. Once checked in, walkers will enjoy a nice walk along the Hocking River via the Hocking Adena Bikeway. You will be treated to delicious snacks at the half way point and come back to the finish line for lunch and some fun. The entire walk is 3 miles long.

properties.name: MS Walk - Cleveland
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1351 Canal Road, Cleveland, OH 44113MS Walk Tower City Amphitheater Cleveland, Ohio Saturday, April 28, 2007 Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Tower City Amphitheater on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at the Tower City Amphitheater in the Flats. Once checked in, walkers will traverse the beautiful city streets of Cleveland, before heading back to the Finish Line at Tower City Amphitheater for a celebratory lunch and some great entertainment! The entire route is 6 miles long. There is also a 3-mile short route available. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk.

properties.name: MS Walk - Columbus
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn19990 Riverside Drive, Powell, Ohio 43065MS Walk Columbus Zoo Columbus, Ohio Saturday, April 28, 2007 Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Columbus Zoo on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The entire MS Walk will take place at the Columbus Zoo prior to it opening on April 28, 2007. This is a new location and we are very excited to be sharing this with our walkers. Walkers will check in, be treated to a great breakfast, and then walk the route through the Zoo. After the walk, MS Walk participants will be able to enter the Zoo and visit all of the wonderful animals and exhibits located at the Columbus Zoo. NOTE: Because the Columbus MS Walk is taking place at the Columbus Zoo, those Walkers will not be permitted to bring their dog to the event.

properties.name: MS Walk - Hartville
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn113480 Congress Lake Avenue, Hartville, Ohio 44632MS Walk Quail Hollow State Park Hartville, Ohio Saturday, April 21, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at Quail Hollow State Park on Saturday, April 21, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at the Manor House at Quail Hollow State Park in Hartville. The MS Walk route offers an invigorating hike through the woods. The route is not paved - and promises to be very muddy this time of year! Please dress accordingly. You may choose to use the accessible route, which is approximately 1/4 mile, or walk on the road that runs through Quail Hollow State Park. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk.

properties.name: MS Walk - Lancaster
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1157 East Fair Avenue, Lancaster, Ohio 43130MS Walk Fairfield County Fairgrounds Lancaster, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Fairfield County Fairgrounds on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS Walk will begin and end at the AAA Building at the Fairfield County Fairgrounds, which is located at 157 East Fair Ave. Once checked in, walkers will enjoy a nice walk through the neighborhoods of historic Lancaster. Children ages 4-9 can also participate in the MS Walk Jr. Walkers will return to the AAA building for a nice lunch and some entertainment. The entire walk is 6 miles long with a 3-mile short route.

properties.name: MS Walk - Mahoning Valley
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn17265 Columbiana-Canfield Road Canfield, OH 44406 MS Walk Canfield Fairgrounds Canfield, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Canfield Fairgrounds on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS Walk will begin and end at the Government Building at the Canfield Fairgrounds. Once checked in, walkers will walk along the grounds of the famous Canfield Fairgrounds, home of the world renowned Canfield Fair. Includes 4 mile and 2 mile route options. Once you hit the finish line, you’ll enjoy a celebratory picnic!

properties.name: MS Walk - Marietta
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1208 3rd St Marietta, Ohio 45750-3001MS Walk Marietta Moose Family Center Marietta, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Marietta Moose Family Center on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS WALK will begin and end at the Marietta Moose Family Center #1823, which is located at 208 3rd Street in Marietta. Once checked in, walkers will traverse the beautiful streets of historical Marietta. The entire walk is 4 miles long. A wonderful lunch will be provided once you return to the Moose Family Center.

properties.name: MS Walk - Massillon
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1505 Erie Street North, Massillon, OH 44646 MS Walk Massillon Recreation Center Massillon, Ohio Saturday, April 28, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Massillon Recreation Center on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at the Massillon Recreation Center in Massillon. After checking in, walkers will be bussed to the starting location for the MS Walk. Walkers will discover the Sippo Valley Trail as they walk along a stretch of the former Wheeling & Lake Erie Railroad bed. Once back to the recreation center, walkers will be treated to a celebratory lunch. The entire route is 4 miles long. There is also a 2-mile short route available. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk.

properties.name: MS Walk - Mentor
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn16477 Center Street, Mentor, OH 44060MS Walk Mentor High School Mentor, Ohio Saturday, April 28, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at Mentor High School on Saturday, April 28, 2007. The MS Walk begins and ends at Mentor High School. Once checked in walkers will traverse the beautiful city bike trails and the path through Mentor Civic Park and part of Lake Metroparks. Once back at the high school, walkers can look forward to a delicious lunch prepared by the wonderful folks at Outback Steakhouse

properties.name: MS Walk - Newark
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1101 W Main St,, Newark, OH 43055 MS Walk Newark Public Library Newark, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at the Newark Public Library on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS Walk will begin and end at the Newark Public Library, which is located at 101 West Main Street in downtown Newark. Once checked in, walkers will stroll the picturesque and historic streets of Downtown Newark. The entire walk is 3 miles long. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk. Enjoy a wonderful lunch upon your return to the library.

properties.name: MS Walk - Zanesville
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1401 Market St., Zanesville, OH 43701

properties.name: MS Walk - Zaneswille
properties.description: Posted by Mpenn1MS Walk Zane’s Landing Park Zanesville, Ohio Saturday, April 14, 2007 Check in begins at 9:00 a.m. Join the National MS Society and help us celebrate the MS Walk at Zane’s Landing Park on Saturday, April 14, 2007. The MS WALK will begin and end at Zane’s Landing Park, which is located at the end of Market Street in Downtown Zanesville. Once checked in, walkers will discover the sights of Zanesville as they walk through this historic area. The entire walk is 3 miles long. Drinks and snacks will be available at rest stops throughout the walk. Once walkers return to the pavilions, they will be treated to a very nice lunch.
